The class of rational languages is the smallest class of
languages containing all sets with 0 or 1 word and which
is closed over the rational operations defined above.

A word is acceped by an automata iff there is a walk starting at the initial
state, ending at one of the allowed final states, and passing through an
allowed transition betweenn staesfor each symbol in the word.
A weighted language P is a map of the form:
As P is often sparse, it can be useful to define
it in terms of its set of non-zero weighted words.
The class of rational weighted languages is the smallest class
of weighted languages that contains all functions nonzero for
only 0 or 1 word and closed over the rational operations above.
sum of X(l)Y(r) for all l and r such that lr = w
NOTE: The above operation is well-defined if and only if X does not contain the empty string.
The weight of a walk through an automata is the product of all of the factors
along the path taken multiplied by the weight of the final state, and the
weight of an arbitrary string is the sum of the weights over all walks.
vector that is everywhere zero except at the initial state
vector that contains the final state weights

A word is acceped by a Bucchi automata iff there is a walk starting at the initial
state, passing through an allowed transition between states for each symbol in the
word, and passing through some subset of the states in F an infinite number of times.
The set of rational infinite languages is equal

where X and Y are (finite) rational languages.

is obtained by starting with the finite
weighted languages, closing them over the
rational operators just presented and then
taking only the words of infinite length.

A bi-diverging language L is a map of the form:
A rational bi-diverging language is a bi-diverging language formed
from the juxtaposition of two rational diverging languages.
